Cracking Electron apps open
entry.summary: I use the draw.io desktop app to make diagrams for my website. I run it on an actual desktop, like Windows or macOS, but the asset pipeline that converts .drawio files, to .pdf, to .svg, and then to .svg again (but smaller) runs on Linux.

entry.title: Gem pristine <gem_name> restores installed gems - #ruby
entry.summary: gem pristine <gem_name>. This command restores installed gems to their original, pristine state using the files stored in the gem cache. here is some documentation. Matt Polito

entry.title: This unicorn startup faked 95% of its users
Skip hidden fields on Phoenix inputs_for - #elixir
entry.summary:
inputs_for accepts a skip_hidden attr which was very useful today. We have a has_many relationship that we are using <.inputs_for> to decompose the nested fields and as it was generating some hidden fields the style was breaking. Tailwind divide on the parent tag and those hidden fields were adding extra separation borders. A way to solve that was calling <.inputs_for twice as this:
<.inputs_for field={@form[:posts]} />
<.inputs_for :let={form} field={@form[:posts]} skip_hidden> <.input type="text" field={form[:title]} label="Title" />

entry.title: Tailwind divide to add border between - #design
entry.summary:
divide classes that helps to add border between elements. So if you want to add a separator border for your children you can try:
01
02
03
And that will add horizontal borders between those nodes.

entry.title: Delete A Rule In UFW - #devops
entry.summary:
uncomplicated firewall (ufw). You run ufw help and see that the entry for delete is delete RULE|NUM delete RULE sudo ufw status, all you see is this Status: active
To Action From -- ------ ---- OpenSSH ALLOW Anywhere 443 ALLOW Anywhere OpenSSH (v6) ALLOW Anywhere (v6) 443 (v6) ALLOW Anywhere (v6) sudo ufw status numbered, which has the rule number in the left hand column. Status: active
To Action From -- ------ ---- [ 1] OpenSSH ALLOW IN Anywhere [ 2] 443 ALLOW IN Anywhere [ 3] OpenSSH (v6) ALLOW IN Anywhere (v6) [ 4] 443 (v6) ALLOW IN Anywhere (v6) sudo ufw delete 3.

Rails config hosts accepts regular expressions - #rails
entry.summary:
Rails.application.config.hosts << /.*\.ngrok\.app/ Rails.application.config.hosts << ".ngrok.app"
But it's still nice to know you can utilize regular expressions if needed!

entry.title: Using `up_only` in ActiveRecord migrations - #rails
entry.summary:
change method on migrations is great so you don't have to specify up and down and if you just want to execute a simple sql update on up then you can use the up_only method: def change add_column :products, :draft, :boolean, default: true
up_only do execute "update products set draft = false" end end

entry.title: Directly fetch a change from a phoenix changeset - #elixir
entry.summary: fetch_change/2. Simply pass the function a changeset, and the name of the column where you want to see the change. changeset = change(%User{}, %{first_name: "John"}) |> fetch_change(:first_name) # => "John"

entry.title: Macro Guard Clauses in Elixir - #elixir
entry.summary:
Lets start by looking at a super basic guard clause here: def greater_than_10(num) when num > 10, do: true def greater_than_10(_), do: false when guard. This is overkill for our situation, but lets say we want the when to use a custom function of ours instead of a basic operation, but when guards don't allow you to directly pass functions to them. defguard that allows you to define custom guards like functions. Let's change our function up and define a guard that checks if our argument is both a integer and even. defmodule Guards do defguard is_even_num(num) when is_integer(value) and rem(value, 2) == 0 end import Guards
def even_num_greater_than_10(num) when is_even_num(num) do case num > 10 do true -> true _ -> false end end
Even though this example is a bit overkill, the option to use custom guards is a cool elixir feature.

entry.title: RIP Google Domains… and 5 big tech stories this week
Custom Radio and Checkbox colors in Tailwind - #html-css
entry.summary:
accent-{color} class, you can customize your form's colors. On your input, simply add the class along with the color of your choice like this: <input type="checkbox" class="accent-red-300" checked>
And the result looks like this! (its an image btw, I'll save you a click)
This works for the accent colors of radio groups as well.

entry.title: High-school student makes React a million times faster
Hack Your Brain With Elaborate Coping Mechanisms
Comparison Validator Also Validates Presence - #rails
entry.summary:
:blank error if the attribute is missing. So you don't have to explicitly add a presence validation if you're also doing a comparison validation (unless you really really want to (I probably still will)). class SomeClass include ActiveModel::Model include ActiveModel::Attributes
attribute :some_number
validates( :some_number, comparison: {greater_than: 8} ) end some_number you'll get a :blank error, and the comparison validation will not run: pry(main)> foo = SomeClass.new pry(main)> foo.valid?; foo.errors.full_messages => ["Some number can't be blank"] some_number, then the comparison validation will run as expected: pry(main)> bar = SomeClass.new(some_number: 3) pry(main)> bar.valid?; bar.errors.full_messages => ["Some number must be greater than 8"] Source
